awd_titl_txt: A Paleoclimatic Examination of Tropical Cyclone-Related Precipitation Variability and Atmospheric-Oceanic Controls Inferred from Longleaf Pine in the Coastal Carolinas
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will analyze the variability of rainfall resulting from tropical cyclones, such as tropical storms and hurricanes, that impacted the coastal regions of North Carolina and South Carolina during the last 300 years.  Because an accurate instrumental record of precipitation from tropical cyclones along the southeastern Atlantic Coast exists only from about 1950 to the present, the new approach refined through the conduct of this project will expand the understanding of the long-term variability of tropical cyclone precipitation and tropical cyclone frequency.  Preliminary research has indicated that longer periods of minimal tropical cyclone precipitation exceeded previously identified recurrence intervals, thereby indicating that the variability in tropical cyclone precipitation is greater than has been experienced recently.  Although this project focuses on several sites in the coastal Carolinas, the proxy record contained in tree-rings of longleaf pine trees that occur throughout the range of land-falling tropical cyclones from Texas to North Carolina offers a viable means to expand basic understanding of the long-term variability of tropical cyclones and their precipitation along the far southeast Atlantic and Gulf coasts.  Project findings and methods will have value for linking paleoclimates with current conditions with observed increases in both flooding and drought events.  Project findings will be shared with governmental agencies and other groups.  An enhanced understanding of variability in total precipitation volume from tropical cyclones will assist planners and management personnel engaged in flood- and drought-mitigation projects.  In addition to providing education and training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, high school seniors engaged in North Carolina's Summer Ventures in Science and Mathematics program will have opportunities to learn about the project.

Tropical cyclone precipitation is critical to groundwater recharge.  It can abruptly end droughts, and it serves an important ecological role.  Tropical cyclone precipitation also causes inland flooding resulting in multiple fatalities, widespread power outages, and billions of dollars in damages.  The investigators engaged in this project will develop a method to determine variations in tropical cyclone precipitation for multiple centuries.  The pattern of longleaf pine tree growth will be determined using a method called cross-dating, and the annual latewood ring width, which develops during tropical cyclone season, will be measured and statistically matched with the instrumental climate record of tropical cyclone precipitation.  The investigators will extend the record of tropical cyclone precipitation more than 200 years beyond that available using the instrumental record.  They will document long-term spatio-temporal variability of tropical cyclone precipitation, and they will examine the bivariate sensitivity of tropical cyclone precipitation to modes of climate variability, such as the North Atlantic Oscillation and Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation.  They also will determine the potential suite of interactive and multivariate influences of these large-scale atmospheric modes on tropical cyclone precipitation. Tree-ring data will be collected non-destructively from live trees and from remnant stumps.  Using statistical regression, mathematical models will reconstruct the historical volume of tropical cyclone precipitation.  Multi-century patterns of tropical cyclone precipitation will be examined for trends, periodicities, and regime shifts using regression-based and wavelet analysis techniques.

por.por_cntn:
Tropical cyclone (TC; tropical depressions, tropical storms, and hurricanes) activity and landfall frequency in the southeastern US exhibit spatiotemporal variability at intra-annual, inter-annual, and inter-decadal time scales. TC precipitation (TCP) is an important facet of the Southeast Atlantic Coastal Region (SACR) hydroclimate as it helps recharge groundwater supplies, can abruptly end severe drought conditions, and serves an important ecological role. Conversely, landfalling TCs often impose substantial societal costs resulting from storm surges, high winds, and inland flooding. Little information is available to determine the natural range of variability and the magnitude for TCP because of the paucity of serially complete meteorological data prior to the 1950s. Thus, incorporating the use of  proxy TCP data, which in this study examined the variability of latewood tree-ring widths of old-growth (i.e., 150-300-year-old trees) longleaf pines that grow near the North Carolina and South Carolina coastline provides: 1) a historical context for better understanding the spatiotemporal variability of TCP, and 2) information that can aid in the development and implementation of drought and flood mitigation plans at various spatiotemporal scales (e.g., municipal and state).

 

Our research resulted in the publication of five articles that:

1) have shown that drier TCP phases lasting decades consistently occur when anomalous troughing in the upper atmosphere (500 hPa) occurs off the U.S. East Coast. In turn, these conditions likely steer Atlantic TCs northward before they approach the coastline. This pattern of drier conditions occurring during anomalous troughing remained operative during our study period of 1750-2015. International Journal of Climatology (https://doi.org/10.1002/joc.6615). 

2) have shown that latewood widths of longleaf pine growing on Carolina bay sand rims have high fidelity with TCP and that latewood sensitivity to TCP increases with trees growing at higher elevations along the rim. Conversely, latewood widths of trees growing on the Carolina bay peripheries have minimal fidelity with TCP. Also, we used Lidar (Light Detection and Ranging) techniques to determine microelevational differences, and this is a novel approach in dendroclimatology. Tree-Ring Research (http://dx.doi.org/10.3959/TRR2019-9).

3) have shown that longleaf pine has the strongest climate/growth relationship with latewood and that the relationship is consistent within the SACR study area of North Carolina and South Carolina. Trees (https://doi.org/10.1007/s00468-021-02093-z).

4) resulted in the creation of a high-resolution gridded TCP dataset to help in understanding the spatial-temporal variability of TCP and how these variations may affect communities, water resources, and ecosystems. Journal of Climate (https://doi.org/10.1175/JCLI-D-18-0885.1).

5) found extremes in TCP amounts from 1700-2018 have increased and that five of the seven most extreme amounts of summed TCP occurred during the late 20th and early 21st centuries. PNAS (http://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2105636118).

 

Our work focused on the value of presenting these findings at professional conferences and to a much broader audience at colloquia and demonstrate the benefits of how the results may be useful for a variety of planning and scientific purposes. For example, understanding the potential for total precipitation volume from TCs informs planners and management personnel regarding community-based flood mitigation projects, particularly considering our findings that the frequency of extreme TCP events has increased during the past half-century.  Likewise, recognition that multidecadal periods of low TC activity along the SCAR region are associated with persistent summertime low-pressure circulation conditions that either minimize or prevent TC landfall helps our understanding of the natural range of variability in TCP. Our findings contribute to the disciplines of: 1) climatology, by expanding the record of TCP to multiple centuries, 2) dendroclimatology, where our use of Lidar data to determine climate/growth responses along microelevational gradients is novel, 3) geography, by demonstrating a better understanding of the spatial patterns of TCP at different geographical scales, and 4) hydrology, via a better understanding of the variability of TCP along the North Carolina and South Carolina coastal plains that can be used during the development of water budgets.

 

The grant provided an opportunity for nine graduate students and three undergraduate students to participate in field and laboratory work associated with this product. Students had supervised training in dendroecological techniques used in the field, and laboratory procedures for processing tree-ring data (crossdating, use of WINDENDRO for measurements, COFECHA for quality control).
